summary.p: Report on the entry of the Elector [Johann Friedrich] of Saxony, the [Landgrave Philipp of] Hesse, and other princes into Donauwörth, after Vogler was allowed to accompany the two mayors of Augsburg, Jakob Herbrot and Hans Welser, there.

- First (according to Herbrot's record) the list of princes (allegedly eleven) who rode into Donauwörth: The Elector of Saxony, his eldest son [Johann Friedrich II.] and his brother [Johann Ernst of Saxe-Coburg], the Landgrave of Hesse, three princes of Brunswick, Duke Franz of Lüneburg, and Prince [Wolfgang] of Anhalt.
- It is believed that the military campaign of these princes comprises 6,000 cavalrymen and 20,000 infantrymen. Many more soldiers are expected to follow. Below is the description of the processions.

- Preliminary report: Vogler arrived in Donauwörth with both mayors on Wednesday, August 4. The following day, they went to a hill where the Landgrave was located, but his camp had not yet been set up. When both mayors requested an audience, they were told that the Landgrave would see them the next day. [On Friday, August 6] they were indeed admitted to the meeting of the two princes and their war councils. During this, letters arrived one after another, which the Landgrave quickly read through himself.

- When Vogler, Welser, and Herbrot [later] went to the camps of the two princes, they rode past the two camps, which were set up near the Danube and Lech, already in the territory of Duke [Wilhelm IV.] of Bavaria, near Rain. These camps were exceedingly impressive!
- Both [military columns] have meanwhile advanced further into Bavaria, which 18 companies (including a Swiss one with 600 men) had already done a few days earlier after leaving Donauwörth.
- The mayors were accompanied by about 65 riders from Herbrot's guild of merchants.
- The Elector of Saxony and the Landgrave of Hesse wrote a letter to Emperor [Charles V.] and renounced their allegiance to him.
- They also wrote to the Duke of Bavaria, urging him to finally choose a side.
- The Emperor has moved from Regensburg to Landshut.
- The Italian and Spanish troops are now with him.
- During the two days [August 5 and 6], a total of 84 companies passed through Donauwörth (not counting the [aforementioned 18] companies of the South Germans and Swiss).

- Description of the entry of the Landgrave's troops into Donauwörth on August 5, lasting from 5 to 3:30 PM. The procession was led by the baggage, followed (according to Hessian custom) by the women and children. Often, a rooster or a hen [in reference to the Hessian coat of arms] as well as dogs could be seen with the wagons. [A description of the procession follows, mentioning, among other things, the five companies that previously served King [Francis I.] of France (namely in his war against England) and were sent to the Landgrave by the people of Strasbourg. Two banner inscriptions are also mentioned.]
- On August 8, Augsburg sent four large cannons to the camp [of the princes] along with about 100 wagons loaded with ammunition, weapons, and provisions.

- Description of the entry of the Elector of Saxony's troops on August 6. [Vogler recalls that] during the two days, a total of 84 companies passed through Donauwörth before settling in Rain [on the Lech]; that six more companies had previously passed through Donauwörth; that meanwhile, the 18 companies (including the Swiss company) had joined the companies [of the princes]. The Elector's procession lasted from 5 to 3 PM. [A description of the procession follows, mentioning Duke Ernst of Brunswick-[Grubenhagen] and Lord Henning of Burtfeld].

div.p: When the earnest, wise, my gracious lords and patrons, both mayors Jacob Herbrot and Johann Welser of the city of Augsburg, out of special friendship, honor, and company with them (at Donauwörth), so that I might see as much as possible of the entry of the two princes of Saxony and Hesse along with other princes through Donauwörth, as briefly noted below.
Item firstly, these are the princes (of whom 11 are said to have ridden in with their entourage and all military equipment) in their own person (according to Mayor Herbrot's handwriting):
The Elector of Saxony. The Landgrave of Hesse. The eldest son of the Elector. The brother of the Elector of Saxony. Three princes of Brunswick. Duke Franz of Lüneburg. The Prince of Anhalt.

The military equipment of the aforementioned princes, as they entered Donauwörth, is estimated at 6,000 well-equipped cavalry and 25,000 infantry. Many more are expected to follow. However, how these entered Donauwörth one after another is roughly recorded below.
Preliminary report

Item on Wednesday, August 4, 1546, we arrived in Donauwörth. In the morning, I rode out with both mayors towards a hill where the Landgrave was located, but the camp had not yet been set up. The two mayors wanted to go to him. Thus, they were told with this message: The Landgrave would come to the city tomorrow with other princes - as indeed happened. In the morning, the two mayors went into a house where Saxony, Hesse, and the war councilors sat in a room for 2 hours, during which a messenger, a letter, came one after another. There Saxony and Hesse sat together. Whatever letters came, the Landgrave himself quickly read, etc.

Item into the camp (of which there are 2: Saxony and Hesse) I rode with both mayors, as we rode to the Elector's and Hesse's camps. But these camps are so arranged, equipped, and beautiful that I cannot say, likewise their size, all against the city of Rain, which belongs to the Duke of Bavaria, and a pass at the Danube and Lech. Item all camps, except for both princes, have moved into Bavarian land; then 18 companies of landsknechts (including 1 ensign from Switzerland among the landsknecht ensigns, carrying his banner in the Swiss manner, with 600 men among them) have also moved through the city of Donauwörth into Bavaria this day.
Item both mayors, Herbrot and Welser, with whom I rode, had (namely Herbrot in his merchant guild with him, all well-armored, black clothing over it) about 65 horsemen.

Item both princes, Elector and Hesse, have written to the Emperor, very friendly, yet lamentable of this matter, thereby renouncing their allegiance to His Imperial Majesty, and thus preserving their honor.
Item they have written to the Duke of Bavaria, not to remain neutral, but to hold on the Imperial or Protestant side, or preserve their honor.
Item the Emperor has moved from Regensburg to the city of Landshut, located in Bavaria.

Item the Italian troops, likewise 11 companies of Spaniards, are said to be with His Imperial Majesty. Item the sum of all companies that have passed through Donauwörth in 2 days is 84 companies, not counting the Swiss and Upper German ones ().

The entry of the Landgrave of Hesse through Donauwörth with all military equipment on August 5 (item in the morning at 5 o'clock it began and lasted until half past four in the afternoon without interruption): Firstly the baggage, of which there is a lot, including women and children, as is the Hessian custom, some children at the breast, mentioned beforehand.
Item on all wagons mostly 1 rooster and hen, also some dogs under the wagons.
Then 1 company of sappers with all equipment.
Then 1 company of cavalry.
But then 2 companies of sappers.
Then 1 lord with his horses.
Then a company of infantry with spears.
Then 2 companies of arquebusiers.

Then 5 companies of landsknechts, who had been with the French against England, and whom the people of Strasbourg sent to the Landgrave and accepted; these soldiers all well equipped, none lacking, also very large, strong, old warriors, the likes of which I have never seen in my life.
Then 3 companies of fine infantry with spears, also well equipped.
Then 1 company with arquebusiers.
Then 1 banner with cuirassiers, very fine and many.

Then 1 company of cuirassiers, and then also a very fine banner of the Landgrave with three lines of gold letters written (the two I could not read; the third says: "God is our strength"), in this the Landgrave himself rode.
Then 1 company of cavalry, 60 members, always three together. [Procession] of the Landgrave
Then 14 main pieces of artillery (cannons), in front of many, 20 large wagons, drawn.
Then 1 company of infantry.
Then another company with cuirassiers.
Then a footfolk.
Then some companies with 400 arquebusiers.
Then 6 companies of very fine infantry, spears, halberds.
Then 1 banner with cavalry train.
In all banners and companies of the Landgrave stands: V. D. M. Y. Æ.

Item on August 8, the city of Augsburg sent to the camp 4 pieces of artillery: The first weighs 92 hundredweight 16 pounds; the second 69 hundredweight 8 pounds; the third 55 hundredweight 25 pounds; the 4th 15 hundredweight 53 pounds.
Item 22 wagons with balls for these 4 pieces.
Item 6 wagons with spears.
Item then with provisions, equipment, armor, it amounted to about 100 wagons.
[Procession of] Saxony:
All companies that passed through Donauwörth are on the land of Bavaria, also towards the city of Rain, totaling 84 companies.
Previously passing through another 6 companies.

Among the aforementioned 18 companies is in the middle of the procession 1 ensign from Switzerland, with 600 Swiss. This procession was among other ensigns and carried his banner in the Swiss manner. The Swiss were strong soldiers, but little armor.
On Friday, August, Saxony entered. Item firstly in the morning at 5 o'clock began to pass through and lasted until 3 o'clock in the afternoon.
Item the supply wagons with provisions, bridges, and all military equipment with very brave horses and heavy load, about 1500 wagons.
Then 1 cavalry train, well equipped, 1 company.
Then 1 white company with sappers, all equipment and their captain, pickaxes, shovels, axes, hoes, about 300.
Then came a hanging wagon, a beautiful old lord. After this lord his cavalry train.
But again a wagon, on which a great lord. On him 24 pieces of beautiful arquebuses, large, very large horses.
Then about 300 beautiful cavalry horses. On this 1 company of riders, 160 horses.
Then three groups of cavalry horses.
Then 1 company of fine cuirassiers, 225.
On this a lord with 18 beautiful horses. Then infantry, 2 companies, with spears and halberds.
Then about 400 arquebusiers.
But 1 company of fine infantry with spears.
Then again 3 companies of infantry with spears and halberds. [Procession of] Saxony Then 1 company of infantry with spears.
On this some arquebusiers.
Then a fine cavalry train of cuirassiers, N., the lord of Burgfeld in his own person.

On him 1 company of cavalry, 160 horses. On this some companies of cavalry, very fine cavalry cuirassiers, 270 horses, among them the Elector in his own person in a black velvet coat riding, and his son. By the Elector's side were his bodyguards, all red trousers and jackets.
And 6 trumpeters on him.

And one on a beautiful black horse. Has 2 drums on it. He played on both drums very cheerfully. On this, the princes, rode 7 princes, among them Duke Ernst, Duke of Brunswick, and others, 1 company of very fine cuirassiers: Were 142 members, always 3 cuirassiers next to each other.
Then again a cavalry train of about 100 horses, ringy. Then some companies with halberds, spears, arquebusiers, about 300. On this again 3 companies with spears.
On this some arquebusiers.
Then their baggage.
Then 2 companies with spearmen.
Then some arquebusiers.
On this 3 lords with 1 banner, 200 horses cuirassiers. Then oxen.
Then sheep.
Then wagons and horse harness.
To Master Heinrich Bullinger to the hands of my dear godfather Jacob Rordorff and Lord Provost Brynwald. Once you have read it, let it be heard, until I come.
